TaxonomicNotes.value: Triturus cristatus formerly was considered to include four subspecies: T. cristatus cristatus; T. c. dobrogicus; T. c. karelinii; and T. c. carnifex. These are now recognized as separate species of the Triturus cristatus superspecies, and the specific name Triturus cristatus (sensu stricto) is attributed to the former nominative subspecies. The exact ranges of members of the Triturus cristatus superspecies are unclear in the central Balkans because of narrow or extensive areas of hybridization.
Formerly included in the genus Salamandra, this taxon was assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
Padial and De la Riva (2004) tentatively consider all Bufo regularis and Bufo mauritanicus records from the Adrar as Bufo xeros [all now under Sclerophrys].

Most Moroccan populations previously considered to belong to this species are now separated as Discoglossus scovazzi (García-París and Jockusch 1999, Fromhage et al. 2004, Vences et al. 2014). North African populations have historically been regarded as a separate subspecies, Discoglossus pictus auritus, from those on European islands. There is, however, little genetic divergence between European and North African groups, and Zangari et al. (2006) considers the species monotypic.

The intraspecific systematics of this species needs further study. Animals from the Altai Mountains have for a long time been considered as a separate subspecies of Rana arvalis or as the species Rana altaica. This has largely been on the basis of their shorter shins and large inner metatarsal tubercle. Similar frogs have since been found in other parts of the range of Rana arvalis (e.g., in the north of European Russia and in the Urals) and in Siberia some animals display transient characters between Rana arvalis and the Altaic taxon. Until this taxonomic issue is fully resolved we include Rana altaica within Rana arvalis.

Investigations of mitochondrial DNA suggest that subpopulations from the southern Caucasus and Central Asia might represent separate species. The taxonomy of Anatolian water frogs (including this species) is still unclear; some authors suggest that the presence of this species in Türkiye cannot be established on the basis of morphometric data.

There are studies that claim that this species represents a species complex and therefore are questioning the identity of marsh frogs e.g. from western Caucasus area (Ermakov et al. 2016). Some studies suggest that parts of its range, at least in the Balkan Peninsula, actually belong to Pelophylax kurtmuelleri (Kolenda et al. 2017).

Prior to Uzzell (1982) (who provisionally resurrected the name), this species was considered to be a synonym of Pelophylax perezi, or, following Pasteur and Bons (1959), a synonym of P. ridibundus. Although northwest African members of the "P. esculentus" complex are here tentatively regarded as P. saharicus, Hemmer, Konrad and Bachmann (1980), suggested that two species were hybridizing in North Africa. Steinwarz and Schneider (1991), considered it probable that P. saharicus is a junior synonym of P. perezi.

Cryptic diversity possibly exists in the Libyan subpopulation (Ibrahim 2013). Nicolas et al. (2014) found their sampled populations from Morocco and Algeria to be genetically distinct, suggesting divergence along the Moulouya River valley dating back approximately 2.6 Mya. Some mitochondrial differentiation has been found between northern and southern populations in Morocco (Lansari et al. 2015). Arano et al. (1998) previously found an east-west pattern of allozyme divergence between the subspecies P. s. saharicus and P. s. rioderoi.

Morphological, ecological and genetic studies on Salamandra algira indicate that there are two major clades further subdivided in several lineages (Beukema et al. 2010, Ben Hassine et al. 2016, Bouzid et al. 2017, Merabet et al. 2016a, Beddek et al. 2018, Dinis et al. 2019, Hernandez and Escoriza 2019), which are recognized as five distinct subspecies: S. a. tingitana (Donaire-Barroso and Bogaerts 2003), S. a. splendens (Beukema et al. 2013), S. a. spelaea (Escoriza and Comas 2007), S. a. algira (Bedriaga 1883), and S. a. atlantica (Hernandez and Escoriza 2019).

This species was previously reported to occur in Cyprus, however, following genetic analysis, these records are now assigned to Pelophylax cypriensis, previously confused under this name (Plötner et al. 2012).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Hyla felixarabica (Gvoždík et al. 2010).
This was previously considered a subspecies of Hyla arborea, until it was elevated to species status by Stöck et al. (2008).

This species is a re-description of the previously elevated subspecies of Triturus karelinii which was known as T. arntzeni (Wielstra et al. 2013). T. anatolicus was previously confused with species (Wielstra and Arntzen 2016).
This species was elevated from its previous status as a subspecies of Bufo bufo by Recuero et al. (2012).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the splits of the broader concept into this and Bufo spinosus (García-Porta et al. 2012, Recuero et al. 2012).

Following genetic analysis, parts of the former range of this species (e.g. Jersey, western and southern France, Andorra, and the Iberian Peninsula) have been assigned to Bufo spinosus which has been elevated from subspecies level (García-Porta et al. 2012, Recuero et al. 2012).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Xenopus poweri (Furman et al. 2015). A previous subspecies of this species Xenopus laevis sudanensis was elevated to a distinct species, and then subsequently synonymised with X. poweri (Furman et al. 2015).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and S. tridactyla (Malyarchuk et al. 2010). Following genetic analysis, some subpopulations in Primorsky Krai in Russia, in eastern China and at the extreme northeast of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea have now been assigned to Salamandrella tridactyla (Malyarchuk et al. 2010).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this species (which as now defined contains the subspecies Pelobates syriacus syriacus and P. s. boettgeri) and Pelobates balcanicus (Dufresnes et al. 2019).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Rana parvipalmata (Dufresnes et al. 2020) from northwest Spain, formerly placed as a subspecies of Rana temporaria.

Dufresnes et al. (2019) revised the taxonomy of Hyla meridionalis and described the genetically distinct Tunisian and eastern Algerian populations, previously identified as a candidate species, as the new species H. carthaginiensis on the basis of evidence that limited genetic admixture suggests "putatively advanced reproductive isolation". The species was simultaneously described by Escoriza and Ben Hassine (2019) as Hyla numidica, using a specimen from Nefza, Tunisia, but this name was published later. H. numidica; is consequently a junior synonym of H. carthaginiensis (Dufresnes and Crochet 2020).


As now defined, H. meridionalis consists of two divergent clades: one restricted to Algeria and possibly the Molouya Valley in adjacent Morocco; and the other being naturally endemic to Morocco (from which all studied naturalized populations are derived) (Dufresnes et al. 2019, Dufresnes and Alard 2020).

Bufotes siculus was synonymized under this species by Speybroeck et al. (2010) and supported by Dufresnes et al. (2019), who note also that this name may not have been validly published. This arrangement has been endorsed by the European Herpetological Society (Speybroeck et al. 2020). This species exhibits little genetic structure across its range, which has been hypothesized to result from recent demographic expansion during interglacial periods (Nicolas et al. 2018).

Further revision of the taxonomy of the Bufotes viridis complex with the use of genetic and biochemical data is needed. There was disagreement over the use of the generic name Pseudepidalea in place of Bufo and now most species have been moved to Bufotes because of non-monophyly of both Bufo and Pseudepidalea.

After Dufresnes et al. (2019) revised the taxonomy of the B. viridis complex, synonymizing B. balearicus and Bufo variabilis within it and clarified range limits between this species and the former synonym B. sitibundus, which they elevated to specific status, encompassing most of the species' former range, Frost ("Amphibian Species of the World") again synonymized B. sitibundus with B. viridis. Bufo perrini was also elevated from subspecies to species level by Dufresnes et al. (2019), but is not recognised by Frost as a separate taxonomic entity.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Pelobates fuscus (Litvinchuk et al. 2013, Suryadnaya 2014).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Triturus ivanbureschi (Wielstra et al. 2013).

This species was elevated from subspecies level of Lissotriton vulgaris (Pabijan et al. 2017). Although there is ongoing discussion about the taxonomic identity of the species (Speybroeck et al. 2020), we follow Frost (2021) in accepting Lissotriton schmidtleri as a valid species.
